Situation1: Laundry needs to be done so clean clothes are available for the family’s activities.
Expectation2: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation2: A technical hurdle is preventing the mentee from advancing on the current project.
Story: I stare at the overflowing laundry basket, the colors and whites tangled together, a silent reminder of the promise I made to my partner last night: “I’ll handle the laundry tomorrow, don’t worry.” The kids have soccer practice in the evening, and everyone needs clean uniforms. I know how much my spouse counts on me to share the load, to keep our little world running smoothly. But my phone buzzes with a reminder—my mentor is expecting an update on my project by noon. I’ve hit a technical wall, and I’m supposed to reach out as soon as I encounter any roadblocks. That’s what she emphasized: “Don’t let things pile up. Communicate early.” My mind races, torn between the hum of the washing machine and the ping of my inbox. If I start the laundry now, I’ll be late sending that email, risking my mentor’s trust. If I write to her first, the laundry will be pushed back, and my spouse will be disappointed. My chest tightens as I stand in the hallway, paralyzed by the weight of both expectations, wishing I could split myself in two.
